questions.text: Mechanism of action of inhibin? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibits FSH

 

Inhibin is a hormone secreted by the granulosa cells in the ovaries. Its primary role is to provide negative feedback on the anterior pituitary gland to regulate the secretion of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).

 

Inhibin specifically inhibits the release of FSH. By doing this, it helps regulate the menstrual cycle and ensures that only one dominant follicle develops during each cycle. This inhibition is crucial for the proper functioning of the reproductive system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increases FSH secretion: This is incorrect because inhibin decreases the secretion of FSH.

 

Option C. Increased estradiol: While inhibin is produced by granulosa cells, which also produce estradiol, inhibin itself does not directly increase estradiol levels.

 

Option D. Inhibits estradiol: This is incorrect because inhibin does not inhibit estradiol; it primarily inhibits FSH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibin's primary mechanism of action is to inhibit the secretion of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) from the anterior pituitary gland, providing negative feedback to regulate the menstrual cycle.

questions.text: Enzyme activated by a decrease in insulin: glucagon ratio is? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glucose 6-phosphatase

 

Glucose 6-phosphatase is an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of glucose-6-phosphate back to glucose. It is activated when the insulin-to-glucagon ratio decreases. This enzyme plays a crucial role in gluconeogenesis, the process of synthesizing glucose from non-carbohydrate sources when blood glucose levels are low.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucokinase: Glucokinase is an enzyme that phosphorylates glucose to glucose-6-phosphate. It is primarily found in the liver and pancreatic beta cells. Glucokinase's activity is influenced by glucose levels, not the insulin-to-glucagon ratio.

 

Option B. Hexokinase: Hexokinase is another enzyme that phosphorylates glucose to glucose-6-phosphate. It is present in various tissues, but its activity is not directly regulated by changes in the insulin-to-glucagon ratio's

 

Option C. Phosphofructokinase (PFK): Phosphofructokinase is an enzyme involved in glycolysis, the metabolic pathway that converts glucose to pyruvate. It plays a role in glucose metabolism but is not activated by a decrease in the insulin-to-glucagon ratio.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Low insulin glucagon ratio means it is fasting state, as in fed state insulin is more. So in fasting state glucose-6-phosphatase will be active as this enzyme is involved in gluconeogenesis, which occurs during fasting.
  • Phosphofructokinase is involved in glycolysis. PFK-1 is active in any situation and PFK-2 is active only in fed state.
  • Glucokinase phosphorylates glucose in liver and pancreas, active in fed state and is induced by insulin.
  • Hexokinase also phosphorylates glucose and is present in all cells of the body. It is active in any situation in body as it is a general enzyme to phosphorylate glucose.

 

Ref- Harper 31st ed pg – 137-138

questions.text: Identify the acid base disorder in a patient with the following values: pH- 7.2 and pCO2 – 80 mm Hg? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Respiratory acidosis

 

Explanation:

 

As pH = 7.2 of the patient’s blood is lower than normal blood pH= 7.35-7.45, so, it’s a case of acidosis. As the acidosis is due to pCO2 = 80 mm of Hg that is higher than normal pCO2 = 35-45 mm of Hg, so, it’s a case of respiratory acidosis rather than metabolic acidosis which occurs due to decreased HCO3- ions.

 

Other options

 

Option A. Metabolic acidosis: This condition is characterized by a decrease in blood pH due to a primary reduction in bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels. It is not associated with elevated pCO2 levels, which are seen in respiratory acidosis.

 

Option B. Metabolic alkalosis: This condition is characterized by an increase in blood pH due to a primary increase in bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels. It is not consistent with the low pH and high pCO2 levels seen in the patient.

 

Option D. Respiratory alkalosis: This condition is characterized by an increase in blood pH due to a primary decrease in pCO2 levels, often caused by hyperventilation. It is the opposite of the patient's condition, which shows low pH and high pCO2 levels.

 

Educational Objective:


Respiratory acidosis is indicated by a low blood pH and elevated pCO2 levels, suggesting impaired respiratory function and CO2 retention as the primary cause of the acidosis.

 

Ref: Dinesh Puri 3rd ed/pg-15

questions.text: A patient with chronic diarrhea develops dermatitis herpetiformis. The physician altered his diet which improved his symptoms. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Celiac disease

 

Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder in which the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine. The immune system mistakenly targets gluten, along with the lining of the small intestine, leading to symptoms such as chronic diarrhea, malabsorption, and weight loss. One of the hallmark dermatological manifestations of celiac disease is dermatitis herpetiformis. This condition presents as a chronic, intensely itchy rash, typically on the elbows, knees, back, and buttocks, and is caused by the deposition of IgA antibodies at the dermoepidermal junction.

 

The improvement of symptoms following the alteration of the patient’s diet to exclude gluten is a classic indicator of celiac disease. Once gluten is removed from the diet, the intestinal inflammation subsides, and symptoms, including dermatitis herpetiformis, typically improve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Whipple disease: Whipple disease is a rare bacterial infection that can cause malabsorption, leading to symptoms such as diarrhea and weight loss. However, it does not typically cause dermatitis herpetiformis, nor does dietary modification alone usually lead to symptom improvement.

 

Option C. Crohn disease: Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that can cause chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and malabsorption. However, it does not cause dermatitis herpetiformis, and dietary changes like removing gluten do not usually lead to the dramatic improvement seen in celiac disease.

 

Option D. Lactose intolerance: Lactose intolerance results from the inability to digest lactose, leading to gastrointestinal symptoms like bloating, diarrhea, and abdominal pain after consuming dairy products. It does not cause dermatitis herpetiformis, and the improvement in symptoms would be related to avoiding dairy, not gluten.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Celiac disease should be suspected in patients presenting with chronic diarrhea and dermatitis herpetiformis, particularly when symptoms improve following a gluten-free diet.

questions.text: The fluorescent in situ hybridization cannot be useful for detection of which of the following genetic defects?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Point mutation

 

Point mutation: Point mutations involve a change in a single nucleotide base pair, which FISH cannot detect because it is designed to detect larger structural changes. For detecting point mutations, more sensitive techniques like polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and specific variants such as single base primer extension assays are used.

 

Other Options:

 

Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) is a molecular cytogenetic technique that uses fluorescent probes binding parts of the chromosome to detect and localize the presence or absence of specific DNA sequences. It is particularly useful for identifying genetic abnormalities such as deletions, amplifications, and translocations by visualizing the chromosomal location of the gene of interest.

 

Option A. Deletion: FISH can detect deletions by showing the absence of a fluorescent signal where the probe should bind.

 

Option C. Amplification: FISH can detect gene amplifications by showing multiple fluorescent signals in the region of interest.

 

Option D: Translocation: FISH can detect translocations by showing split signals in different parts of the chromosome or in different chromosomes, indicating that parts of the chromosome have been rearranged.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FISH is not suitable for detecting point mutations but is effective for identifying larger genetic abnormalities such as deletions, amplifications, and translocations.

choices.text: Normal leukocyte counts

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in Gaisböck syndrome? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypotension

 

Gaisböck syndrome, also known as stress polycythemia or stress erythrocytosis, is characterized by a chronic relative increase in red blood cell count due to reduced plasma volume, not an actual increase in RBC production. Patients typically exhibit the following features:

 

  • Hypertension, not hypotension
  • Relative erythrocytosis
  • Normal leukocyte counts
  • Obesity

 

Note – DD - Polycythemia: Patients with polycythemia typically present with splenomegaly, Patients with Gaisböck syndrome do not exhibit splenomegaly.

 

Key Features of Gaisböck Syndrome:

 

  • Relative Erythrocytosis: An apparent increase in RBC count due to decreased plasma volume.
  • Hypertension: Elevated blood pressure is common in these patients.
  • Normal Leukocyte Counts: There is no increase in white blood cells.
  • Obesity: Many patients with Gaisböck syndrome are obese.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Erythrocytosis: Erythrocytosis is a hallmark of Gaisböck syndrome due to reduced plasma volume.

 

Option C. Normal leukocyte counts: Patients with Gaisböck syndrome typically have normal leukocyte counts.

 

Option D. Obesity: Obesity is commonly associated with Gaisböck syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gaisböck syndrome is characterized by relative erythrocytosis, hypertension, normal leukocyte counts, and obesity. Hypotension & splenomegaly is not a feature of this syndrome.

questions.text: Which Section of the IPC deals with the punishment of perjury? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 193

 

Perjury (false evidence) means intentional making of a false statement by a person who was under a legal obligation (e.g. under oath) to speak the truth.

 

Section 193 IPC (Now, BNS 229): Punishment for Perjury (false evidence). Specifies the punishment for giving false evidence under oath, which can be up to 7 years of imprisonment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 191: Defines the act of giving false evidence under oath but does not specify the punishment. (BNS 227)

 

Option B. 192: Deals with the fabrication of false evidence but not directly related to perjury. (BNS 228)

 

Option D. 197: Deals with issuing false certificates and provides the same punishment as perjury, up to 7 years, but it is not specifically for perjury. (BNS 234)

 

Educational Objective:

 

IPC related to false evidence:

 

191 IPC: Definition of Perjury (false evidence): Giving false evidence under oath

 

193 IPC: Punishment for Perjury (false evidence): up to 7 years

 

197 IPC: Issuing false certificates- same punishment as that of false evidence (upto 7 years)

 

201 IPC: Causing disappearance of evidence of offence or giving false information to screen offender: Upto 07 years. (BNS 238)

questions.text: Below is an electron microscopy depiction of a cellular structure. Determine the type of cell being depicted. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hairy cell

 

Hairy cells are seen in Hairy cell leukemia. It is a B-cell tumor. Peripheral smear shows pancytopenia; hairy cells. Flow cytometry shows CD11/25/103 + cells. Annexin –A is the best marker.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Target cell: can be seen in thalassemia, hepatic disease with jaundice, hemoglobin C disorders, and the post splenectomy state.

 

 

Option C. Gaucher cell: is found in Gaucher’s disease which occurs due to absence of beta glucocerebrosidase enzyme.

 

 

Option D. Sickle cells:  are seen in sickle cell anemia. HbS has altered solubility and high chance of polymer formation especially with dehydration or hypoxemia causing alteration in shape. On rehydration, it is reversible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hairy cells are seen in hairy cell leukemia, characterized by B lymphocytes with hair-like projections, and are identified using electron microscopy and specific markers like CD11c, CD25, CD103, and Annexin-A.

questions.text: An individual experienced a dog bite. Both the person and the dog are up-to-date with their vaccinations. The person's medical history includes a splenectomy performed five years ago. What is the optimal course of action for managing this situation? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Amoxiclav

 

  • Amoxicillin/clavulanate (Augmentin) is generally considered the first-line prophylactic treatment for animal bites.
  • Appropriate tetanus and rabies prophylaxis as indicated should also be a part of caring for a patient who has sustained a dog bite, as well as local debridement and thorough cleaning of the wound

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Observation: Observation alone is not sufficient due to the risk of infection, especially in an asplenic individual.

 

Option C. Metronidazole: This antibiotic is not typically used as monotherapy for animal bites as it does not cover the range of bacteria commonly involved.

 

Option D. Ciprofloxacin: While it has some coverage, it is not the first-line treatment for dog bites and lacks the broad coverage provided by amoxicillin/clavulanate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Amoxicillin/clavulanate is the optimal course of action for prophylactic treatment following a dog bite, especially in individuals with increased infection risk, such as those with a history of splenectomy.
  • Thorough wound care and appropriate prophylaxis for tetanus and rabies should also be part of the management plan.

choices.text: Active Na+ reabsorption, passive CI- reabsorption, passive K+ secretion, active secretion of HCO3-
Passive Na+ reabsorption, active CI- reabsorption, passive K+ secretion, active secretion of HCO3-
Passive Na+ secretion, active CI- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-
Active Na+ reabsorption, passive CI- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-

questions.text: The second phase of saliva secretion involves: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Active Na+ reabsorption, passive CI- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-

 

First, sodium ions are actively reabsorbed from all the salivary ducts and potassium ions are actively secreted in exchange for the sodium. Excess sodium reabsorption over potassium secretion, creates electrical negativity of about -70 millivolts in the salivary ducts; this in turn causes chloride ions to be reabsorbed passively. Therefore, the chloride ion concentration in the salivary fluid falls to a very low level, matching the ductal decrease in sodium ion concentration.

 

Active Na+ reabsorption

 

(The ductal cells actively transport sodium ions (Na+) from the saliva into the interstitial fluid surrounding the ducts. This reabsorption of sodium ions helps in concentrating the saliva). Conc.  15 mEq/L

              ↓

Passive Cl- reabsorption

(As sodium ions are reabsorbed, chloride ions (Cl-) passively follow along due to electrical charge balance. This results in the reabsorption of chloride ions from the saliva into the interstitial fluid). Conc.  15 mEq/L

              ↓

Active K+ secretion

(The ductal cells actively secrete potassium ions (K+) into the saliva. This secretion helps in maintaining the concentration of potassium ions within the saliva). Conc.  30 mEq/L

              ↓

Passive secretion of HCO3-

(Hydrogen carbonate ions (HCO3-) are passively secreted from the ductal cells into the saliva. This helps in maintaining the alkaline nature of saliva, which aids in buffering acidic substances and maintaining oral pH). Conc. 50 to 70 mEq/L,

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Active Na+ reabsorption, passive Cl- reabsorption, passive K+ secretion, active secretion of HCO3-: Incorrect. While Na+ and Cl- processes are correct, K+ secretion is active, not passive.

 

Option B. Passive Na+ reabsorption, active Cl- reabsorption, passive K+ secretion, active secretion of HCO3-: Incorrect. Na+ reabsorption and Cl- reabsorption roles are reversed, and K+ secretion is active.

 

Option C. Passive Na+ secretion, active Cl- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-: Incorrect. Na+ reabsorption should be active, not passive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The second phase of saliva secretion involves active Na+ reabsorption, passive Cl- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, and passive secretion of HCO3-, crucial for maintaining electrolyte balance and pH in saliva.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure. (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flexor carpi radialis

 

  • The marked structure in the image is the Flexor Carpi Radialis.
  • The flexor carpi radialis muscle is a long, superficial muscle of the forearm that belongs to the anterior muscle group and lies in the first layer.
  • It is a relatively thin muscle located on the anterior part of the forearm.
  • It arises in the humerus epicondyle, close to the wrist area.
  • It is a superficial muscle that becomes very visible as the wrist comes into flexion.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option. B. Flexor Carpi Ulnaris: The flexor carpi ulnaris can be palpated by locating the bony landmarks associated to the muscle including the medial epicondyle, the olecranon process and the pisiform bone. After identifying the bony landmarks, the person is asked to perform ulnar deviation and wrist flexion simultaneously, which will help locate the FCU muscle.

 

 

Option. C. Palmaris Longus: The Palmaris longus (PL) muscle is a long, slender muscle which is usually present in the superficial volar compartment of the forearm, interposed between the Flexor Carpi Ulnaris and the Flexor Carpi Radialis muscles. This muscle is absent in about 14% of the population.

 

 

Option. D. Extensor Carpi Radialis: Extensor carpi radialis is a muscle that can be found in the posterior compartment of the forearm. It is partly overlapped by brachioradialis and these muscles often blend together.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The marked muscle tendon in the image is of the flexor carpi radialis muscle.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the given image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aberrant right subclavian artery

 

The CT scan image provided shows an anatomical variant where there is an extra vessel coursing behind the esophagus towards the right side. Normally, there are three major arch arteries visible at this level. However, in this image, an additional vessel is seen, which is characteristic of an aberrant right subclavian artery.

 

The aberrant right subclavian artery is an anatomical variation where the right subclavian artery arises as the fourth branch of the aortic arch and passes posterior to the esophagus. This can lead to a condition known as dysphagia lusoria, where the esophagus is compressed by the artery, causing difficulty in swallowing (dysphagia).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right sided aortic arch: This condition involves the aortic arch itself being positioned on the right side, which is not indicated by the presence of an extra vessel behind the esophagus in this image.

 

Option C. Tracheal diverticulum: A tracheal diverticulum would appear as an air-filled outpouching from the trachea. The image does not show any such outpouching or abnormality of the trachea.

 

Option D. Esophageal duplication: This is a rare congenital condition where a duplicated segment of the esophagus is present. The image does not show an additional lumen or any signs indicative of esophageal duplication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An aberrant right subclavian artery is an anatomical variant where the artery arises as the fourth branch of the aortic arch and courses posterior to the esophagus, often leading to dysphagia lusoria due to esophageal compression.

questions.text: Identify the papillae of the tongue that serve a mechanical function but do not contribute to taste sensation. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Filiform

 

Filiform papillae are the most numerous papillae on the surface of the tongue. They are elongated, keratinized projections that cover the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Unlike other papillae, filiform papillae do not contain taste buds. Their primary function is to provide a rough surface that aids in the mechanical aspect of chewing by creating an abrasive texture that helps manipulate food.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Circumvallate: These papillae are located near the back of the tongue in a V-shaped arrangement just in front of the sulcus terminalis. They contain taste buds on their lateral surfaces and are responsible for the perception of bitter tastes.

 

Option C. Foliate: Foliate papillae are located on the lateral edges of the tongue. They contain taste buds that are responsible for the perception of sour tastes, although they are less prominent in humans compared to some other animals.

 

Option D. Fungiform: These mushroom-shaped papillae are scattered across the tongue's surface, particularly near the tip and sides. They contain taste buds and are responsible for the perception of sweet, salty, and umami tastes.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Four types of papillae on the tongue:

  1. Filiform
  2. Fungiform
  3. Circumvallate
  4. Foliate

 

Taste buds are barrel-shaped structures located in the epithelium of the foliate and fungiform papillae, as well as on the lateral sides of the circumvallate papillae.

 

Taste buds are absent in the filiform papillae, which are the most numerous and smallest papillae on the surface of the tongue. They cover the entire dorsal surface of the tongue.

questions.text: A Doctor comes to the court to present his postmortem report. What kind of witness is the Doctor?(FMGE  2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Expert witness

 

Explanation:

 

Expert witness is a person who has been trained or skilled in technical or scientific subject. He can volunteer a statement, if he feels that justice is likely to be miscarried owing to the court having failed to elicit an important point.

 

In this case, a doctor presenting a postmortem report is providing technical opinion based on medical expertise, making them an expert witness. An expert witness is typically required to give opinions on their area of expertise, and in this scenario, the doctor's analysis and interpretation of the postmortem findings classify them as such.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hostile witness: This refers to a witness who deliberately does not tell the truth or speaks lies in court. This can apply to both common and expert witnesses.

 

Option C. Common witness: This refers to a witness providing factual information without any specialized knowledge or opinions. In this scenario, since the doctor is giving an opinion based on medical expertise, they are not a common witness.

 

Option D. Hearsay witness: This is someone who reports what they have been told by another person rather than what they personally observed. Hearsay witnesses are generally not considered reliable in court.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A doctor presenting a postmortem report in court is classified as an expert witness due to their specialized medical knowledge and ability to provide technical opinions. ​

 

Note – Doctor is both common and Expert witness

questions.text: Which of the following substances can be used for new bone formation in cases of non-union fracture?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bone morphogenetic protein

 

PROPERTIES OF GRAFT MATERIALS

 

 

 

  • Atrophic non union (absent callus, poor bone biology, lack of blood supply) are fixed by internal fixation with biologic stimulation.
  • Biologic stimulation is done with bone graft and bone morphogenetic protein (BMP).
  • Although the gold standard in nonunion therapy is the transplantation of autologous bone graft, missing bone regeneration subsequent to transplantation of autologous bone graft poses a serious disadvantage for the patients. Therefore, in the last few years, this therapy was combined with the application of bone morphogenetic protein-7 (BMP-7).
  • Use of BMP-7 is approved for tibial non-unions.
  • BMP-2 is approved for 1 level degenerative disk disease in spinal fusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium phosphate. Calcium Phosphate Cement is a useful bone substitute for benign bone tumor surgery. It provides excellent osteoconductivity and long-lasting stability without internal fixation.

 

Option B. Caclium sulphate. Calcium sulfate is a synthetic ceramic bone graft substitutes which has an osteoconductive property. It is a bio-inert material which gets resorbed over a period of weeks and fibrovascular tissue takes its place which eventually allows neovascularisation and bone formation within the area. Use of calcium sulfate as a bone graft substitutes avoids the complications and morbidity associated with autograft like infection.

 

Option C. PMMA. Polymethylmethacrylate is one of the most enduring materials in orthopaedic surgery. It has a central role in the success of total joint replacement and is also used in newer techniques such as percutaneous vertebroplasty and kyphoplasty.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BMP helps in bone formation and repair. Thus, for the union of non-united fractures by surgery, it is used as an autograft material.

questions.text: Affinity maturation is due to: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Somatic hypermutation

 

Affinity maturation is a process that occurs in B cells during an immune response, leading to the production of antibodies with increased affinity for their antigen. This process is primarily driven by somatic hypermutation (SHM).

 

Mechanism:

 

  • Somatic Hypermutation (SHM): This involves the introduction of point mutations at a high rate in the variable regions of the immunoglobulin (Ig) genes in activated B cells. These mutations occur in the DNA encoding the variable regions of both heavy and light chains of the antibody molecule.
  • Selection for High Affinity: B cells that produce antibodies with higher affinity for the antigen are selectively expanded. Those with mutations that increase the affinity of the antibody for its antigen are positively selected and proliferate, whereas B cells with lower affinity or non-functional antibodies are eliminated.
  • Result: This process leads to the production of high-affinity antibodies over time, enhancing the effectiveness of the immune response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isotype Switching: Also known as class switch recombination, this process changes the antibody isotype (e.g., from IgM to IgG) but does not directly affect the antigen-binding affinity.

 

Option C. mRNA Splicing: This process involves the removal of introns from pre-mRNA to produce mature mRNA, but it is not involved in affinity maturation.

 

Option D. VDJ Rearrangement: This process generates the initial diversity of the antigen receptor repertoire by recombining variable (V), diversity (D), and joining (J) gene segments. It occurs before exposure to antigen and does not contribute to the increased affinity seen in affinity maturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Affinity maturation, which results in the production of high-affinity antibodies, is primarily due to somatic hypermutation (SHM) of immunoglobulin genes in B cells, coupled with selective survival and proliferation of B cells producing high-affinity antibodies.

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors of vulval cancer except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vulval hamartoma

 

Vulval cancer has several known risk factors, which include:

 

  • Chronic vulval irritation: Persistent irritation and inflammation can contribute to the development of vulval cancer.
  • Immunosuppressive conditions: Conditions such as pregnancy and HIV infection can compromise the immune system, increasing the risk of vulval cancer.
  • HPV (Human Papillomavirus): Infection with HPV, particularly strains 16 and 18, is a significant risk factor.
  • Smoking: Smoking is a known risk factor for various cancers, including vulval cancer.
  • Condyloma (anogenital warts): Caused by HPV, these warts can lead to changes in vulval cells that may progress to cancer.
  • Sexually transmitted diseases (STDs): History of STDs can increase the risk due to the association with HPV and chronic inflammation.
  • Vulvar dystrophies: Conditions like lichen sclerosus can predispose individuals to vulval cancer.

 

Vulval hamartoma is not a risk factor for vulval cancer. Hamartomas are benign, disorganized clusters of tissue that do not typically transform into malignant tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vulval dystrophy: Vulval dystrophies, such as lichen sclerosus, are risk factors for vulval cancer due to chronic irritation and inflammation.

 

Option C. Smoking: Smoking is a well-documented risk factor for many cancers, including vulval cancer.

 

Option D. Vulval warts: Vulval warts, often caused by HPV, can lead to cellular changes that increase the risk of vulval cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vulval hamartomas are not a risk factor for vulval cancer, while chronic irritation, immunosuppressive conditions, HPV infection, smoking, anogenital warts, STDs, and vulvar dystrophies are known risk factors.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 680, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 334

questions.text: Identify this maneuver: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ritgen maneuver

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts the Ritgen maneuver, which is performed during the second stage of labor to control the delivery of the fetal head. This maneuver involves controlled extension of the head to minimize perineal trauma. The pressure is applied on the fetal chin through the perineum while simultaneously controlling the speed of delivery of the head with the other hand.

 

This helps in a gradual delivery of the head, reducing the risk of severe perineal tears.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pinard maneuver: This maneuver is used during breech delivery to assist in delivering the legs by hooking them at the popliteal fossa.

 

 

Option B. Lovset maneuver: This is also used in breech delivery, specifically to help deliver the arms that are positioned over the head (nuchal arms).

 

 

Option D. Mauriceau maneuver: This is used for delivering the after-coming head in a breech presentation, involving the application of pressure on the maxilla and supporting the body of the baby to facilitate head delivery.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ritgen maneuver involves controlled extension of the fetal head during delivery to minimize perineal trauma and ensure a smooth birth process.

questions.text: The mother of a 12-year-old girl was worried that her daughter is shorter when compared with her classmates. On examination, the child had a webbed neck, low hairline, and shield chest. A provisional diagnosis of Turner's syndrome was made. Which of the following is a likely finding to be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bilateral small streak ovaries

 

The likely finding seen in a patient with Turner syndrome is bilateral small streak ovaries.

 

Turner syndrome results from complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome. It is characterized by hypogonadism in phenotypic females. It is the most common sex chromosome abnormality in females. Three types of karyotypic abnormalities are seen

 

  • Missing an entire X chromosome - this results in a 45X0 karyotype.
  • Structural abnormalities of the X chromosomes
  • Mosaics - they will have 45X along with one or more karyotypically normal or abnormal cell types. Examples are 45X/46XX, 45X/46XY, 45X/47XXX, 45×/46X, ¡(X)(q10).

 

Important features associated with Turner's syndrome:

 

 

  • Short stature
  • Webbing of neck
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Cubitus valgus
  • Streak ovaries
  • Infertility, amenorrhea
  • Peripheral lymphedema at birth
  • Low posterior hairline
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Pigmented nevi
  • Coarctation of aorta

 

Normal secondary sex characteristics do not develop during puberty. The genitalia remain infantile, breast development is inadequate, and pubic hair is scarce. In adults, short stature and amenorrhea are especially important in establishing the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic dissection: While Turner syndrome is associated with cardiovascular abnormalities, such as coarctation of the aorta and bicuspid aortic valve, aortic dissection is less common in children and typically occurs in adults with significant aortic disease.

 

Option B. Subluxation of lens: Subluxation of the lens is a feature of Marfan syndrome, not Turner syndrome.

 

Option C. Mitral valve prolapse: Mitral valve prolapse is more commonly associated with connective tissue disorders like Marfan syndrome and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. Turner syndrome is more characteristically associated with left-sided heart defects like coarctation of the aorta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome is characterized by features such as short stature, webbed neck, shield chest, and streak ovaries, leading to primary ovarian insufficiency, infertility, and amenorrhea. The diagnosis is confirmed by karyotyping, and the most likely finding in Turner syndrome patients is bilateral small streak ovaries.

choices.text: Follow up 6 monthly for 2 years and then yearly follow up

questions.text: A 63-year-old female patient presented with a 5x1 cm lump in the left upper outer quadrant, with no axillary lymph node involvement. Mammography revealed BIRADS 4b staging. She underwent breast conservation surgery, and the final HE reports showed high nuclear grade DCIS with 7 mm margin clearance. What is the further management? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adjuvant radiotherapy

 

After breast-conserving surgery (BCS) for ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), adjuvant radiotherapy is typically recommended. Radiotherapy has been shown to significantly reduce the risk of local recurrence after BCS for DCIS. In this patient, despite having a 7 mm margin clearance, the presence of high nuclear grade DCIS warrants the use of adjuvant radiotherapy to minimize the risk of local recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adjuvant chemotherapy: Chemotherapy is primarily used for invasive breast cancers, especially when there is a high risk of systemic spread. DCIS is a non-invasive form of breast cancer, and hence systemic chemotherapy is not typically indicated.

 

Option C. Follow up 6 monthly for 2 years and then yearly follow up: Regular follow-up is crucial for any patient who has undergone treatment for breast cancer, but it is not the primary management strategy immediately after surgery for high nuclear grade DCIS.

 

Option D. Trastuzumab therapy: Trastuzumab is a targeted therapy used for HER2-positive invasive breast cancers. DCIS that is HER2-positive does not typically receive trastuzumab therapy, as the benefits of such treatment in non-invasive cancer have not been clearly established.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Based on the Van Nuys prognostic index, the patient’s score is: High grade- 3 points, Margins 7 mm-2 points, Size 5 cm- 3 points and age 63 years- 1 point= 9 points.

 

The recommended next step in the patient's management would be adjuvant radiotherapy for scores 7 to 9.

 

 

Score: 4 to 6: wide excision alone

 

7 to 9: Adjuvant radiotherapy

 

10 to 12: Mastectomy

questions.text: A patient sustained an injury to the head and now presents with blood collected around his eyes. Attachment of which of the following structures leads to this condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Loose areolar layer

 

Explanation:

 

The condition, where blood collects around the eyes following a head injury, is known as "raccoon eyes" or "black eyes".

 

Layers of the scalp -

 

The scalp consists of five layers, which can be remembered using the mnemonic "SCALP":

 

  1. Skin
  2. Connective tissue (superficial fascia)
  3. Aponeurotic layer (epicranial aponeurosis)
  4. Loose areolar layer
  5. Periosteum (pericranium)

 

 

Among these layers, the loose areolar layer (4th layer) is the key to understanding the development of raccoon eyes. This layer lacks bony attachments anteriorly and is continuous with the eyelids. When a head injury occurs, the emissary veins or other vessels in this layer may rupture, causing blood to accumulate. Since the loose areolar layer is continuous with the eyelids, the blood can easily spread and collect around the eyes, resulting in the characteristic black eye appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial fascia: Incorrect. Although the superficial fascia is one of the layers of the scalp, it is not the layer responsible for the continuity with the eyelids and the development of raccoon eyes.

 

Option C. Periosteum: Incorrect. The periosteum, also known as the pericranium, is the innermost layer of the scalp, firmly attached to the underlying bone. It does not have continuity with the eyelids and is not the cause of raccoon eyes.

 

Option D. Pericranium: Incorrect. The pericranium is another name for the periosteum, the innermost layer of the scalp. It is not responsible for the development of raccoon eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The loose areolar layer of the scalp, which lacks bony attachments anteriorly and is continuous with the eyelids, is responsible for the development of raccoon eyes following a head injury due to the accumulation and spread of blood from ruptured vessels.

questions.text: Cannabinoids are not approved for treatment of (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rett syndrome

 

  • Cannabinoids, including cannabidiol (CBD), are not currently approved for the treatment of Rett syndrome. 
  • Rett syndrome is a rare genetic neurological disorder, and while there is ongoing research into potential treatments, cannabinoids are not among the approved therapies for this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dravet Syndrome: Cannabidiol (CBD) is approved for the treatment of Dravet Syndrome, a severe form of epilepsy. It is used to reduce the frequency of seizures in patients with this condition.

 

Option B. Tuberous sclerosis: Cannabidiol (CBD) is also approved for the treatment of seizures associated with Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC). It has been shown to reduce seizure frequency in patients with TSC.

 

Option D. Lennox Gastaut syndrome: Cannabidiol (CBD) is approved for the treatment of Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome, another severe form of epilepsy. It is used to help reduce the frequency of seizures in patients with this syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, cannabinoids, specifically cannabidiol (CBD), are not approved for the treatment of Rett syndrome, whereas they are approved for use in Dravet Syndrome, Tuberous Sclerosis, and Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome.

questions.text: A child was brought to OPD with cola colored urine, his mother gives history of odynophagia, dysphagia, fever, and membrane over tonsils as given in image. Which among the following is likely cause?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Streptococcal Tonsillitis

 

Explanation:

 

Streptococcal tonsillitis is characterized by a tenacious exudate that forms a membrane over the tonsils. The image shows a thick, white exudate covering the tonsils, which is typical for streptococcal tonsillitis. This condition can present with symptoms such as fever, odynophagia (painful swallowing), dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), and cola-colored urine (a sign of possible post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Faucial diphtheria: Presents with a thick, grayish membrane that bleeds when removed. It is typically accompanied by significant cervical lymphadenopathy and neck swelling, which is not described in the case.

 

 

Option B. Vincent angina: Also known as acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis, is associated with ulcerations and necrotic areas rather than forming a thick membrane over the tonsils. The description and image do not match this presentation.

 

 

Option D. Oral Candidiasis: Generally presents with widespread white plaques that can be scraped off, revealing red, inflamed tissue underneath. The membrane shown in the image is more localized to the tonsils, which is more characteristic of streptococcal tonsillitis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Streptococcal tonsillitis can present with a thick, white exudate covering the tonsils, accompanied by fever, painful swallowing, and potential complications such as post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, indicated by cola-colored urine.

questions.text: Identify the structures as marked in the image: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Errector pili muscle

 

In the image, the marked structure corresponds to the Errector pili muscle (C).

Errector Pili Muscle is a tiny muscle attached to the base of a hair follicle. When this muscle contracts, it causes the hair to stand upright, a phenomenon known as "goosebumps."

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sebaceous glands: Incorrect because the sebaceous glands are associated with hair follicles, but the marked structure is clearly a muscle, not a gland. Sebaceous Glands are small oil-producing glands present in the skin of mammals. They are usually associated with hair follicles and release sebum, which helps to lubricate the skin and hair.

 

Option B. Eccrine glands: Incorrect because these glands open directly onto the skin surface without any connection to the hair follicle, whereas the marked structure is connected to a hair follicle. Eccrine Glands are sweat glands that are not associated with hair follicles and play a key role in thermoregulation by secreting sweat.

 

Option D. Apocrine glands: Incorrect because apocrine glands are larger and typically located deeper in the dermis. These are sweat glands usually associated with hair follicles in areas such as the armpits and groin. They secrete a thicker, milky sweat that, when broken down by bacteria, can produce body odor.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Errector pili muscle is a small muscle attached to hair follicles responsible for causing hairs to stand on end when contracted, leading to "goosebumps."

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents in surgery OPD with midline swelling in the neck. The swelling moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. What is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroglossal cyst

 

  • Pathology – Remnant of thyroglossal duct
  • Most common site – midline à Subhyoid
  • C/F – Presents in 2nd /3rd decade of life as midline neck swelling which moves up on tongue protrusion and on deglutition.
  • Treatment - Sistrunk’s operation
  • Long standing thyroglossal cyst has a risk of papillary carcinoma thyroid

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Branchial cyst: Failure of obliteration of branchial cleft. Cystic swelling (soft)- typically in a teenager. Swelling at upper 1/3rd + middle 1/3rd junction of sternocleidomastoid.

 

 

Option C. Plunging ranula: Presents as Swelling in floor of mouth, Fluctuation present, Brilliant transillumination.

 

 

Option D. Dermoid cyst: Caused when skin and skin structures become trapped during fetal development.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A midline neck swelling that moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue is characteristic of a thyroglossal cyst, which is a remnant of the thyroglossal duct.
  • The treatment is typically surgical removal via the Sistrunk procedure.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain that had been ongoing for the past 24 hours. He reported that he had been consuming alcohol heavily for the past few weeks. The physical examination revealed tenderness in the upper abdomen with no visible signs of jaundice. Pancreatitis was suspected, and a CT scan was performed, which revealed lesions with fluid collected near the body of the pancreas. The patient was started on appropriate treatment, and blood tests were ordered to help diagnose the condition. Which enzyme is most likely to be elevated in this scenario? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serum lipase

 

  • An alcoholic patient with acute pancreatitis is most likely to have elevated serum lipase levels.
  •  Clinical findings and elevated pancreatic enzymes in the plasma are used to diagnose acute pancreatitis.
  • Lipase is a more sensitive and specific marker of acute pancreatitis than amylase, which can be elevated in other conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum GGT : GGT (Gamma-glutamyltransferase) is an enzyme primarily found in the liver. It is an important marker for liver disease, especially conditions associated with bile duct obstruction. Elevated GGT would not specifically indicate pancreatitis.

 

Option B. CEA : CEA (Carcinoembryonic antigen) is a tumor marker, primarily used to monitor certain types of cancers, particularly colorectal cancer. It can be elevated in some pancreatic cancers as well, but it's not specifically used to diagnose or monitor acute pancreatitis.

 

Option D. Serum bilirubin: Bilirubin is a product of red blood cell breakdown and is processed by the liver. Elevated serum bilirubin levels can indicate liver disease or a blockage of the bile duct, which can be due to a stone, tumor, or other causes. In the context of pancreatitis, elevated bilirubin can be seen in biliary pancreatitis when a gallstone obstructs the common bile duct, but it's not a specific marker for pancreatitis itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Serum lipase is the most specific enzyme for diagnosing acute pancreatitis, especially in cases related to alcohol consumption.
  •  It rises within 12 to 24 hours of pancreatic injury and remains elevated for 7-14 days, making it a crucial diagnostic marker for this condition.

choices.text: Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm
Urgently wheel the patient to OT for surgery
Surgery is indicated only if aneurysm is > 70mm

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient, during his routine annual checkup, is found to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 40 mm in diameter on USG abdomen. Which of the following is true about the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm

 

Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm: True. Generally, surgery (either open surgical repair or EVAR) is recommended for asymptomatic male patients when the AAA reaches a diameter of 5.5 cm (55mm) or greater. The risk of rupture increases significantly as the diameter surpasses this threshold, so this is the currently accepted cutoff for intervention in many guidelines.

 

Surgery is indicated in asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm only if its diameter is more than 55mm.

 

If the diameter is less than 55mm, regular ultrasound monitoring is required. This is because elective open surgery has a higher rate of mortality when compared to conservative management for aneurysms of size <55mm.

 

Other Options:

 

The size of an AAA determines the risk of rupture, and this risk informs the decision for surgical intervention.

 

Option A. Urgent endovascular aneurysm repair: Not necessarily true for a 40mm AAA. Endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) is a less invasive method than open surgery, but it is not typically done urgently for aneurysms of this size unless they are symptomatic or rapidly increasing in size.

 

Option C. Urgently wheel the patient to OT for surgery: Not true for a 40mm AAA. As the aneurysm is still below the general threshold for surgical intervention, there's no need for urgent operation unless there are other complicating factors (e.g., rapid growth or symptoms).

 

Option D. Surgery is indicated only if aneurysm is >70mm: Not true. Waiting for an AAA to reach 70mm before considering surgery would expose the patient to a very high risk of rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surgery (open surgical repair or EVAR) is recommended for asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysms when the diameter reaches 55mm or greater due to the increased risk of rupture beyond this size. Regular monitoring is advised for smaller aneurysms.

questions.text: MgSO₄ toxicity: all are monitored except? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Routine serum Mg level


Magnesium sulfate (MgSO₄) is commonly used in obstetrics to prevent seizures in preeclampsia. Monitoring for toxicity is crucial, and the primary clinical parameters to monitor include respiratory rate (RR), urine output, and deep tendon reflexes (DTR). A decrease in these parameters can indicate magnesium toxicity. Routine measurement of serum magnesium levels is not standard practice unless clinical signs of toxicity are present or there is concern based on monitored parameters. Serum levels are checked only if there is clinical suspicion of toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RR (Respiratory Rate): Monitoring respiratory rate is critical because respiratory depression is one of the first signs of magnesium toxicity. A rate below 12 breaths per minute can indicate toxicity and necessitates intervention.

 

Option B. Urine output: Urine output is monitored because reduced kidney function can lead to magnesium accumulation and toxicity. An output of less than 30 mL/hour suggests the need for caution and potential dose adjustment.

 

Option C. DTR (Deep Tendon Reflexes): DTRs are closely monitored as they are among the first clinical signs to diminish with rising magnesium levels. Loss of reflexes indicates that magnesium levels are dangerously high.

 

Educational Objective:


Routine serum magnesium levels are not typically monitored during magnesium sulfate therapy unless clinical signs of toxicity are present.

questions.text: Which nerve passes through the foramen marked in the image below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Inferior alveolar nerve

 

The marked structure is the mandibular foramen, which is an opening located just below the mandibular angle.

 

  • The inferior alveolar nerve (IAN) is a branch of the mandibular nerve (CN V3).
  • The IAN descends behind the lateral pterygoid muscle, passing between the sphenomandibular ligament and the mandibular ramus, and enters the mandibular canal via the mandibular foramen.
  • The mandibular foramen is the entry point for the IAN and the vessels of the mandible.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lingual nerve:

 

  • It is a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3), which is the third division of the trigeminal nerve.
  • The lingual nerve provides general sensory innervation (touch, pain, temperature) to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • It is closely associated with the chorda tympani nerve (a branch of the facial nerve) which carries taste fibers from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. However, the lingual nerve itself doesn't carry taste sensation; it just provides a pathway for the chorda tympani nerve.

 

Option B. Mandibular nerve:

 

  • The mandibular nerve is the third division (V3) of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V), which is the main sensory nerve of the face.
  • It has both sensory and motor components.
  • The sensory branches of the mandibular nerve include the buccal, lingual, and inferior alveolar nerves, which innervate areas such as the lower teeth, gingiva, skin of the cheek, and anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • Its motor fibers innervate the muscles of mastication (chewing) and other muscles like the mylohyoid, anterior belly of the digastric, tensor tympani, and tensor veli palatini.

 

Option C. Chorda tympani nerve:

 

  • It's a branch of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) and carries taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • It also carries preganglionic parasympathetic fibers to the submandibular and sublingual salivary glands, which play a role in salivation.
  • While it is not a branch of the mandibular nerve, it is closely associated with the lingual nerve (a branch of V3) in the oral cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inferior alveolar nerve is another major branch of the mandibular nerve (V3) which provides sensory innervation to the lower teeth (mandibular teeth) and the surrounding gingiva. Before it enters the mandibular canal in the jaw, it gives off a branch called the mental nerve, which exits the jaw through the mental foramen to supply sensation to the lower lip and chin. The inferior alveolar nerve also carries motor fibers to the mylohyoid muscle and the anterior belly of the digastric muscle.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles form the pelvic diaphragm?

 

1. Iliococcygeus

2. Pubococcygeus

3. Obturator internus

4. Deep transverse perenei

(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 2

 

Explanation:

 

Iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus are parts of the pelvic diaphragm, which is also known as the levator ani. The pelvic diaphragm is a muscular partition that separates the pelvic cavity above from the perineum below. It consists of two paired muscles, the levator ani and the coccygeus (also known as the ischiococcygeus or the pubococcygeus), and their fascial coverings.

 

The levator ani muscle is a broad, thin muscle that forms the floor of the pelvic cavity. It consists of three parts: the pubococcygeus, the iliococcygeus, and the puborectalis.

 

  • Pubococcygeus muscle is the most medial of the three, and it arises from the pubic bone and the fascia covering the obturator internus muscle.
  • Iliococcygeus muscle arises from the fascia covering the obturator internus muscle and the ischial spine.
  • Puborectalis muscle is a sling-like muscle that forms a loop around the anorectal junction, and it arises from the pubic bone.

 

The coccygeus muscle is a small, triangular muscle that lies posterior to the levator ani muscle. It arises from the ischial spine and the sacrospinous ligament and inserts onto the coccyx.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option C. The obturator internus forms the lateral wall of the ischioanal fossa and is not a part of the levator ani.

 

Option D. The deep transverse perineal muscle is the content of the deep perineal space and contributes to the formation of the perineal body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pelvic diaphragm is formed by the iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus muscles, which are part of the levator ani muscle group. These muscles, including the puborectalis and coccygeus, contribute to the floor of the pelvic cavity and provide structural support, separating the pelvic cavity above from the perineum below.

questions.text: A young man underwent a surgery on his chest after a trauma an year ago and has developed a lesion as shown. Which of the following is a probable diagnosis in the patient? (NEETPG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Keloid

 

The image and clinical history are indicative of a keloid, which is a type of raised scar that grows excessively and extends beyond the original wound boundaries.

 

Keloid:

 

  • Definition: Keloids are overgrowths of scar tissue that develop around a wound, usually after the wound has healed. They are benign and result from an overproduction of collagen.
  • Appearance: Keloids are raised, thick, and can be pink, red, or dark in color. They often grow larger than the original wound and do not regress over time.
  • Location: Commonly occur on the chest, shoulders, earlobes, and cheeks but can appear anywhere on the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemangioma: Hemangiomas are benign tumors made up of blood vessels. They usually appear as red or purple marks and are often present at birth or develop shortly after.

 

Option C. Normal scar: A normal scar typically lies flat against the skin and does not extend beyond the boundary of the original wound. It is usually lighter in color compared to keloids.

 

Option D. Hamartoma: Hamartomas are benign, focal malformations that resemble neoplastic tissue but grow at the same rate as the surrounding tissues. They do not typically present as raised scars.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keloids are characterized by an excessive overgrowth of scar tissue that extends beyond the boundaries of the original wound, often appearing thick and raised. They are more common in areas such as the chest, shoulders, earlobes, and cheeks. The clinical image and description provided align with the diagnosis of a keloid.

questions.text: Maternal infection that may lead to teratogenic effect is: [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) All of the above

 

Explanation

 

All listed infections—Chickenpox, Rubella, and CMV (Cytomegalovirus)—can potentially lead to teratogenic effects if a mother contracts them during pregnancy. Here's a brief explanation of how each can impact fetal development:

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Chickenpox: Infection in early pregnancy can lead to congenital varicella syndrome, which includes skin scarring, limb abnormalities, and neurologic disorders.

 

Option B. Rubella: Known for its teratogenic potential if contracted in the first trimester; can cause congenital rubella syndrome, leading to cataracts, deafness, heart defects, and neurological damage.

 

Option C. CMV: The most common viral cause of congenital infections leading to developmental disabilities, including hearing loss, vision loss, and neurodevelopmental disorders.

 

Educational objective :

 

Maternal infection that may lead to teratogenic effect is : TORCH infection

 

  • Toxoplasmosis
  • Other (includes infections such as Syphilis, Varicella-Zoster, Parvovirus B19, and Zika virus)
  • Rubella
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
  • Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV)

 

Note – Now, also includes – Treponema pallidum, HIV, Hep. B viruses

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is found to be positive for HBsAg and HBeAg and is diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B. The viral load of the patient was 2 x 10^5 IU/mL and ALT is found to be doubled. What is the appropriate management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tenofovir

 

The patient is diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B, as indicated by the positive HBsAg and HBeAg, which are markers of infection and infectivity, respectively. The viral load of 2 x 105 IU/mL and elevated ALT levels suggest active viral replication and liver inflammation.

 

HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): This is a marker of infection. Its presence indicates that the person is infectious.

 

HBeAg (Hepatitis B e antigen): This is a marker of infectivity. It indicates that the virus is replicating and the patient is highly infectious.

 

HBV DNA: This is a marker of viral replication. In chronic hepatitis B, a high level of HBV DNA correlates with an increased risk of complications such as cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

The decision to start treatment in chronic hepatitis B is primarily based on the levels of HBV DNA and ALT. According to guidelines, treatment is indicated if:

 

  1. HBV DNA is more than 2000 IU/mL.
  2. ALT is elevated (more than 2 to 3 times the upper limit of normal).

 

In this patient, both criteria are met.

 

Tenofovir is preferred for its efficacy and lower risk of resistance compared to other options like lamivudine. Tenofovir is also favored over interferon-based therapies due to better durability of response and lower side effect profile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lamivudine: This drug is no longer preferred due to a high risk of resistance.

 

Option C. Peg IFN for 52 weeks: Pegylated interferon is not preferred due to less favorable response rates and a higher side effect profile compared to tenofovir.

 

Option D. Combined peg IFN with lamivudine: Combination therapy with pegylated interferon and lamivudine is not recommended due to increased side effects and no significant improvement in efficacy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tenofovir is the preferred treatment for chronic hepatitis B with high viral load and elevated ALT levels due to its efficacy and lower risk of resistance.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions are more susceptible to infections caused by catalase-positive organisms:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic granulomatous disease

 

Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is an immunodeficiency disorder that makes patients particularly susceptible to infections by catalase-positive organisms. This condition arises from a defect in the NADPH oxidase complex in phagocytes, which is crucial for the production of reactive oxygen species used to kill ingested pathogens.

 

Key points about CGD:

 

  • Pathophysiology: In CGD, phagocytes (e.g., neutrophils and macrophages) are unable to produce reactive oxygen species due to a defective NADPH oxidase enzyme. This impairs the killing of certain bacteria and fungi.
  • Catalase-positive organisms: These organisms can neutralize hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), a reactive oxygen species that the host cells might produce. Catalase-positive bacteria include Staphylococcus aureus, Serratia marcescens, Aspergillus species, Nocardia, and Pseudomonas.
  • Recurrent Infections: Patients with CGD frequently suffer from recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly with catalase-positive organisms due to their inability to effectively kill these pathogens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyper IgM syndrome: This immunodeficiency disorder is characterized by elevated levels of IgM and low levels of other immunoglobulins due to defects in class-switch recombination. Patients are more prone to infections but not specifically with catalase-positive organisms.

 

Option C. Job syndrome (Hyper-IgE syndrome): Patients with Job syndrome have elevated levels of IgE and suffer from recurrent staphylococcal skin abscesses, pneumonia, and other infections. However, their susceptibility is not specifically related to catalase-positive organisms.

 

Option D. Chediak-Higashi syndrome: This is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by defects in lysosomal trafficking, leading to impaired phagocytosis and recurrent bacterial infections. While patients are prone to infections, their susceptibility is not specifically to catalase-positive organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is an immunodeficiency disorder that makes patients particularly susceptible to infections by catalase-positive organisms due to a defect in the NADPH oxidase enzyme in phagocytes.

questions.text: Identify this instrument used in the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Piper forceps

 

Piper forceps are specifically designed for the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech presentations. Their unique shape allows them to grasp the head of the baby gently and guide it through the birth canal without applying excessive pressure. The long, curved shanks of Piper forceps are particularly adapted for use when the baby is in breech position, making them the most appropriate tool for this scenario.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wrigley forceps: These are outlet forceps used when the fetal head is at +3 station, fully or nearly fully rotated. They are not designed for use in breech presentations.

 

 

Option C. Kielland forceps: These are rotational forceps used when the fetal head is high and unrotated. They are meant for complex cases where rotation of the head is necessary, not for the aftercoming head in breech.

 

 

Option D. Dass forceps: These are low forceps used when the fetal head is at +2 station. They are not suitable for the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech as they are not designed for such specific maneuvering.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Piper forceps are the instrument of choice for the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech presentations due to their specialized design that facilitates safe extraction.

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy presented with gum bleeding, easy bruising, and fatigue. He was suffering from fever for 1 month and on examination, he had pallor and a petechial rash distributed all over the body. His peripheral smear revealed macrocytes and his corrected reticulocyte count was 0.5%. Bone marrow revealed few fatty streaks, no immature cells, and no inflammatory cells. What should be the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Idiopathic Acquired Aplastic Anemia

 

The patient's presentation of gum bleeding, easy bruising, fatigue, fever, pallor, and petechial rash suggests Pancytopenia. Pancytopenia can result from several conditions, but the key clues here are:

 

  • Bone marrow findings: The bone marrow shows few fatty streaks, no immature cells, and no inflammatory cells, indicating a hypocellular marrow.
  • Corrected reticulocyte count: A low corrected reticulocyte count (0.5%) indicates poor bone marrow response.

 

These findings are characteristic of idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia, a condition where the bone marrow fails to produce adequate amounts of blood cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Disseminated TB: Disseminated TB usually presents with systemic symptoms and may show a cellular bone marrow due to granulomas and other inflammatory changes, which is not consistent with the findings of a hypocellular marrow.

 

Option C. Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH): PNH typically presents with hemolytic anemia, thrombosis, and sometimes pancytopenia. However, it usually shows a cellular marrow unless it is associated with aplastic anemia. In exams, PNH is generally considered a cause of cellular marrow.

 

Option D. Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS): MDS usually presents with a hypercellular or normocellular marrow with dysplastic changes. It can cause pancytopenia, but the marrow is typically not hypocellular except in rare cases of hypoplastic MDS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia should be considered in patients presenting with pancytopenia, bleeding, bruising, fatigue, and hypocellular bone marrow without significant inflammatory or immature cells. The diagnosis is supported by a low corrected reticulocyte count and clinical findings consistent with bone marrow failure.

questions.text:
PQLI indicators include: [NEET PG 2024]

 

  1. Literacy rate
  2. Infant mortality rate
  3. Life expectancy at birth
  4. Income per capita
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Only two of these

 

The Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) is a measure used to assess the quality of life in different countries. It focuses on three main indicators: health, education, and living standards. Specifically, these indicators include:

 

1. Literacy Rate (Education): This measures the education level within a population and is included in the PQLI.

 

2. Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) (Living Standards): This measures the number of infants who die before reaching one year of age, reflecting living conditions and healthcare quality. It is included in the PQLI.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Life Expectancy at Birth: This is not included in the PQLI; instead, PQLI considers life expectancy at age one.

 

4. Income per Capita: This is not part of the PQLI; income measurements are used in the Human Development Index (HDI) but not in PQLI.

 

Thus, only the literacy rate and infant mortality rate are included in the PQLI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PQLI measures the quality of life based on literacy rate, infant mortality rate, and life expectancy at age one, excluding income and life expectancy at birth.

 

Remember – PQLI range – 0 – 100 (India - 65)

choices.text: Lead poisoning
Iron deficiency anemia
Hemolytic anemia

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presented with a history of fatigue and tiredness. On investigation, he was found to have Hb = 9 gm% and MCV =101 FL. Peripheral smear examination showed macrocytic RBC and hyper-segmented neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely etiology? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chronic alcoholism

 

The given findings are suggestive of macrocytic anemia, which can be seen in chronic alcoholics.

 

Peripheral smear showing macrocytic RBCs and hyper-segmented neutrophils are characteristic features of megaloblastic anemia.

 

 

Chronic alcoholics also have deficiency of folic acid due to:

 

  • Folate accumulation in the liver
  • Excessive urinary loss
  • Impaired folate metabolism
  • Chronic alcoholics frequently have insufficient dietary intake.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lead poisoning: Lead poisoning typically causes microcytic anemia rather than macrocytic anemia. Peripheral smear findings in lead poisoning include basophilic stippling of RBCs, not macrocytic RBCs and hyper-segmented neutrophils.

 

Option B. Iron deficiency anemia: Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by microcytic, hypochromic RBCs, which contrasts with the macrocytic RBCs and hyper-segmented neutrophils seen in this patient.

 

Option C. Hemolytic anemia: Hemolytic anemia generally presents with normocytic or slightly macrocytic RBCs, but not to the extent seen in megaloblastic anemia. Additionally, hyper-segmented neutrophils are not a typical feature of hemolytic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Macrocytic anemia with hyper-segmented neutrophils on a peripheral smear is characteristic of megaloblastic anemia, often due to folate deficiency, which is commonly seen in chronic alcoholics due to impaired folate metabolism and poor dietary intake.

questions.text: A homosexual man presented with painful defecation, foul-smelling protruding mass through anus which is non-reducible. Biopsy of the mass shows squamous cell carcinoma of the anus. What will be the next line of management? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chemoradiation

 

For a patient diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal, the first line of management is chemoradiation (called the Nigro regimen). This approach provides good tumor control, preserves the anal sphincter function, and avoids a permanent colostomy. If chemoradiation fails or if there's a recurrence, surgical interventions like APR might be considered.

 

  • This is a combination treatment modality that uses both chemotherapy and radiation therapy to treat cancer. Chemoradiation is the primary treatment for squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal. It provides both local control of the tumor and treats potential microscopic disease. The Nigro regimen, combining 5-FU with mitomycin C or cisplatin and external beam radiation, has shown excellent results in treating this cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colostomy: Colostomy might be used as a temporary or permanent measure in cases where the anus or rectum is obstructed or needs to be bypassed. It's not the primary treatment for anal squamous cell carcinoma but may be used in certain situations to manage symptoms or complications.

 

Option C. Excision: While excision could be considered for some tumors, for anal squamous cell carcinoma, simple excision might not offer the best oncological outcomes compared to chemoradiation. Excision alone without addressing potential microscopic disease can lead to recurrence.

 

Option D. Abdominoperineal Resection (APR): This is a surgical procedure in which the anus, rectum, and sigmoid colon are removed. It results in a permanent colostomy. Abdominoperineal resection was historically the treatment for anal cancer. However, with the success of chemoradiation in treating squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal, APR is now reserved for those who don't respond to chemoradiation or have recurrent disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary treatment for squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal is chemoradiation, which preserves anal sphincter function and avoids the need for a permanent colostomy.

choices.text: Colposcopy and biopsy
Follow-up after 6 months

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is diagnosed with carcinoma in situ (CIS) of the cervix and no obvious macroscopic growth. What is the next line of management? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conization

 

  • Carcinoma in situ is Stage 0 Cancer.
  • It means it involves the entire thickness of the epithelium without invasion of the basement membrane.
  • This should be followed by a conization as the woman is 30 years old and conization will provide us with a biopsy specimen as well as be curative
  • If family is complete/ elderly patient, simple hysterectomy should be done

 

Treatment for Different stages of cervical cancer

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy: While effective, it is more invasive and typically reserved for those who have completed childbearing or for older patients.

 

Option C. Colposcopy and biopsy: This is used for further evaluation but is not the definitive treatment for CIS when the diagnosis is already confirmed.

 

Option D. Follow-up after 6 months: Follow-up without intervention is not appropriate for CIS due to the risk of progression to invasive cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a young woman diagnosed with carcinoma in situ (CIS) of the cervix, conization is the recommended next step, providing both diagnostic and therapeutic benefits.

 

Ref: FIGO Revised Staging of Cervical Cancer, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15th Edition, Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 8th edition page367,
